trans-unit.source: Add Mobile Services to an existing app (Windows Phone) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Add Mobile Services to an existing app (Windows Phone) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to get started using Mobile Services to leverage data in your Windows Phone app.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to get started using Mobile Services to leverage data in your Windows Phone app.

trans-unit.source: Add Mobile Services to an existing app
trans-unit.target: Add Mobile Services to an existing app

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to add Azure Mobile Services as a backend data source for a Windows Phone 8.1 Silverlight app.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to add Azure Mobile Services as a backend data source for a Windows Phone 8.1 Silverlight app.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will download a Visual Studio project for an app that stores data in memory, create a new mobile service, integrate the mobile service with the app, and view the changes to data made when running the app.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will download a Visual Studio project for an app that stores data in memory, create a new mobile service, integrate the mobile service with the app, and view the changes to data made when running the app.

trans-unit.source: To add Mobile Services to a Windows Phone Store 8.1 app, see [this version of the tutorial](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-universal-dotnet-get-started-data.md).
trans-unit.target: To add Mobile Services to a Windows Phone Store 8.1 app, see [this version of the tutorial](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-universal-dotnet-get-started-data.md).

trans-unit.source: The mobile service that you create in this tutorial supports the .NET runtime in the Mobile Service.
trans-unit.target: The mobile service that you create in this tutorial supports the .NET runtime in the Mobile Service.

trans-unit.source: This will allow you to use .NET languages and Visual Studio for server-side business logic in the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This will allow you to use .NET languages and Visual Studio for server-side business logic in the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: To create a mobile service that lets you write your server-side business logic in JavaScript, see the [JavaScript backend version](mobile-services-windows-phone-get-started-data.md) of this topic.
trans-unit.target: To create a mobile service that lets you write your server-side business logic in JavaScript, see the [JavaScript backend version](mobile-services-windows-phone-get-started-data.md) of this topic.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires the following:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires the following:

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 Update 2, or a later version.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 Update 2, or a later version.

trans-unit.source: A Microsoft Azure account.
trans-unit.target: A Microsoft Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see Azure Free Trial.
trans-unit.target: For details, see Azure Free Trial.

trans-unit.source: Download the GetStartedWithData project
trans-unit.target: Download the GetStartedWithData project

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is built on the [GetStartedWithMobileServices app](https://code.msdn.microsoft.com/Add-Azure-Mobile-to-a-8b906f72), which is a Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 app project for Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is built on the [GetStartedWithMobileServices app](https://code.msdn.microsoft.com/Add-Azure-Mobile-to-a-8b906f72), which is a Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 app project for Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: Download the C# version of the GetStartedWithMobileServices sample app from the [Developer Code Samples site](https://code.msdn.microsoft.com/Add-Azure-Mobile-to-a-8b906f72).
trans-unit.target: Download the C# version of the GetStartedWithMobileServices sample app from the [Developer Code Samples site](https://code.msdn.microsoft.com/Add-Azure-Mobile-to-a-8b906f72).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]To create a Windows Phone Silverlght 8.1 app, just change the target OS in the downloaded Windows Phone Silverlight 8 app project to Windows Phone 8.1.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]To create a Windows Phone Silverlght 8.1 app, just change the target OS in the downloaded Windows Phone Silverlight 8 app project to Windows Phone 8.1.

trans-unit.source: To create a Windows Phone Store app, download the [Windows Phone Store app version](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=397372) of the GetStartedWithData sample app project.
trans-unit.target: To create a Windows Phone Store app, download the [Windows Phone Store app version](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=397372) of the GetStartedWithData sample app project.

trans-unit.source: Run Visual Studio with administrative privileges by right clicking Visual Studio and clicking **Run as administrator**.
trans-unit.target: Run Visual Studio with administrative privileges by right clicking Visual Studio and clicking **Run as administrator**.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open the downloaded project and examine the MainPage.xaml.cs file.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open the downloaded project and examine the MainPage.xaml.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Notice that added **TodoItem** objects are stored in an in-memory **ObservableCollection<TodoItem>**.
trans-unit.target: Notice that added **TodoItem** objects are stored in an in-memory **ObservableCollection<TodoItem>**.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, choose a deployment target for the app.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, choose a deployment target for the app.

trans-unit.source: You can deploy to a Windows Phone device or to one of the emulators that are included with the Windows Phone SDK.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy to a Windows Phone device or to one of the emulators that are included with the Windows Phone SDK.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial we demonstrate deploying to an emulator.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial we demonstrate deploying to an emulator.

trans-unit.source: Press the **F5** key.
trans-unit.target: Press the **F5** key.

trans-unit.source: This will build, deploy, and start the app for debugging.
trans-unit.target: This will build, deploy, and start the app for debugging.

trans-unit.source: In the app, type some text in textbox, then click **Save** to save a few items in-memory in the app.
trans-unit.target: In the app, type some text in textbox, then click **Save** to save a few items in-memory in the app.

trans-unit.source: App with in-memory storage
trans-unit.target: App with in-memory storage

trans-unit.source: Notice that the text for each `TodoItem` is displayed below the refresh button along with a check box that allows you to mark the item completed.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the text for each `TodoItem` is displayed below the refresh button along with a check box that allows you to mark the item completed.

trans-unit.source: Create a new mobile service
trans-unit.target: Create a new mobile service

trans-unit.source: Download the mobile service project and add it to the solution
trans-unit.target: Download the mobile service project and add it to the solution

trans-unit.source: If you haven't already done so, download and install [Visual Studio Professional 2013](https://go.microsoft.com/fwLink/p/?LinkID=391934), or a later version.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't already done so, download and install [Visual Studio Professional 2013](https://go.microsoft.com/fwLink/p/?LinkID=391934), or a later version.

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/), click your new Mobile Service and in the quickstart page click the **Windows** platform, then under **Get Started**, expand **Connect an existing Windows or Windows Phone app**.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/), click your new Mobile Service and in the quickstart page click the **Windows** platform, then under **Get Started**, expand **Connect an existing Windows or Windows Phone app**.

trans-unit.source: Download the mobile service project
trans-unit.target: Download the mobile service project

trans-unit.source: Under **Download and publish your service to the cloud**, click **Download**.
trans-unit.target: Under **Download and publish your service to the cloud**, click **Download**.

trans-unit.source: This downloads the Visual Studio project that implements your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This downloads the Visual Studio project that implements your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Unzip the personalized service starter solution you downloaded and copy the folders that were in the zip file into the same **C#** directory where the Get Started with Data solution file (.sln) is located.
trans-unit.target: Unzip the personalized service starter solution you downloaded and copy the folders that were in the zip file into the same **C#** directory where the Get Started with Data solution file (.sln) is located.

trans-unit.source: This makes it easier for NuGet Package Manager to keep all the packages in sync.
trans-unit.target: This makes it easier for NuGet Package Manager to keep all the packages in sync.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio's Solution Explorer, right click your solution for the Getting Started with Data Windows Store app.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio's Solution Explorer, right click your solution for the Getting Started with Data Windows Store app.

trans-unit.source: Click **Add** and then click **Existing Project**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Add** and then click **Existing Project**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Add Existing Project** dialog, navigate to the mobile service project folder that you moved into the **C#** directory, select the C# project file (.csproj) in the service subdirectory, and click **Open** to add the project to your solution.
trans-unit.target: In the **Add Existing Project** dialog, navigate to the mobile service project folder that you moved into the **C#** directory, select the C# project file (.csproj) in the service subdirectory, and click **Open** to add the project to your solution.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio in Solution Explorer, right click the service project you just added and click **Build** to verify that it builds with no errors.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio in Solution Explorer, right click the service project you just added and click **Build** to verify that it builds with no errors.

trans-unit.source: During the build, NuGet package manager may need to restore some NuGet packages that are referenced in the project.
trans-unit.target: During the build, NuGet package manager may need to restore some NuGet packages that are referenced in the project.

trans-unit.source: Right click the service project again.
trans-unit.target: Right click the service project again.

trans-unit.source: This time click **Start new instance** under the **Debug** context menu.
trans-unit.target: This time click **Start new instance** under the **Debug** context menu.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio opens the default web page for your service.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio opens the default web page for your service.

trans-unit.source: You can click **try it now** to test methods in your mobile service from the default web page.
trans-unit.target: You can click **try it now** to test methods in your mobile service from the default web page.

trans-unit.source: Mobile service try it now page
trans-unit.target: Mobile service try it now page

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio hosted your mobile service locally in IIS Express by default.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio hosted your mobile service locally in IIS Express by default.

trans-unit.source: You can see this by right clicking the tray icon for IIS Express on your taskbar.
trans-unit.target: You can see this by right clicking the tray icon for IIS Express on your taskbar.

trans-unit.source: Update the Windows Phone app to use the mobile service
trans-unit.target: Update the Windows Phone app to use the mobile service

trans-unit.source: In this section you will update the Windows Phone app to use the mobile service as a backend service for the application.
trans-unit.target: In this section you will update the Windows Phone app to use the mobile service as a backend service for the application.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer in Visual Studio, right click the Windows Phone app project and click **Manage NuGet Packages**.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer in Visual Studio, right click the Windows Phone app project and click **Manage NuGet Packages**.

trans-unit.source: In the Manage NuGet Packages dialog, search for **WindowsAzure.MobileServices** in the online packages collection and click to install the Azure Mobile Services Nuget Package.
trans-unit.target: In the Manage NuGet Packages dialog, search for **WindowsAzure.MobileServices** in the online packages collection and click to install the Azure Mobile Services Nuget Package.

trans-unit.source: Then close the dialog.
trans-unit.target: Then close the dialog.

trans-unit.source: Install NuGet package
trans-unit.target: Install NuGet package

trans-unit.source: Back in the Azure Management Portal, find the step labeled **Connect your app and store data in your service**.
trans-unit.target: Back in the Azure Management Portal, find the step labeled **Connect your app and store data in your service**.

trans-unit.source: Copy the code snippet that creates the `MobileServiceClient` connection.
trans-unit.target: Copy the code snippet that creates the `MobileServiceClient` connection.

trans-unit.source: Connect your app snippet
trans-unit.target: Connect your app snippet

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open App.xaml.cs.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open App.xaml.cs.

trans-unit.source: Paste the code snippet at the beginning of the `App` class definition.
trans-unit.target: Paste the code snippet at the beginning of the `App` class definition.

trans-unit.source: Also add the following `using` statement at the top of that file and save the file.
trans-unit.target: Also add the following `using` statement at the top of that file and save the file.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open MainPage.xaml.cs, add the using statement at the top of the file:
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open MainPage.xaml.cs, add the using statement at the top of the file:

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio in MainPage.xaml.cs, replace the `MainPage` class definition with the following definition and save the file.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio in MainPage.xaml.cs, replace the `MainPage` class definition with the following definition and save the file.

trans-unit.source: This code uses the Mobile Services SDK to enable the app to store it's data in a table provided by the service instead of being stored locally in-memory.
trans-unit.target: This code uses the Mobile Services SDK to enable the app to store it's data in a table provided by the service instead of being stored locally in-memory.

trans-unit.source: The main three methods are `InsertTodoItem`, `RefreshTodoItems`, and `UpdateCheckedTodoItem`.
trans-unit.target: The main three methods are `InsertTodoItem`, `RefreshTodoItems`, and `UpdateCheckedTodoItem`.

trans-unit.source: These three methods allow you to asynchronously insert, query, and update your data collection to a table in Azure.
trans-unit.target: These three methods allow you to asynchronously insert, query, and update your data collection to a table in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Test the Windows Phone app with the service hosted locally
trans-unit.target: Test the Windows Phone app with the service hosted locally

trans-unit.source: In this section you will use Visual Studio to test the app and mobile service locally on your development workstation.
trans-unit.target: In this section you will use Visual Studio to test the app and mobile service locally on your development workstation.

trans-unit.source: In order to test the mobile service hosted locally in IIS Express from a Windows Phone device or one of the Windows Phone emulators, you have to configure IIS Express and the workstation to allow connections to the workstation's IP address and port.
trans-unit.target: In order to test the mobile service hosted locally in IIS Express from a Windows Phone device or one of the Windows Phone emulators, you have to configure IIS Express and the workstation to allow connections to the workstation's IP address and port.

trans-unit.source: Windows Phone devices and emulators connect as non-local network clients.
trans-unit.target: Windows Phone devices and emulators connect as non-local network clients.

trans-unit.source: Configure IIS Express to allow remote connections
trans-unit.target: Configure IIS Express to allow remote connections

trans-unit.source: Test the app against the mobile service in IIS Express
trans-unit.target: Test the app against the mobile service in IIS Express

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio open the App.xaml.cs file and comment out the `MobileService` definition you recently pasted to the file.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio open the App.xaml.cs file and comment out the `MobileService` definition you recently pasted to the file.

trans-unit.source: Add a new definition to make the connection based on the IP address and port that you configured on the workstation.
trans-unit.target: Add a new definition to make the connection based on the IP address and port that you configured on the workstation.

trans-unit.source: Then save the file.
trans-unit.target: Then save the file.

trans-unit.source: Your code should look similar to the following...
trans-unit.target: Your code should look similar to the following...

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, press the F7 key or click **Build Solution** from the Build menu to build both the Windows Phone app and the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, press the F7 key or click **Build Solution** from the Build menu to build both the Windows Phone app and the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Verify both projects build with no errors in the output window of Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Verify both projects build with no errors in the output window of Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key or click **Start Debugging** from the Debug menu to run the app and host the mobile service locally in IIS Express.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key or click **Start Debugging** from the Debug menu to run the app and host the mobile service locally in IIS Express.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Make you you did run Visual Studio with the **Run as administrator** option.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Make you you did run Visual Studio with the **Run as administrator** option.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, IIS Express may not load your applicationhost.config changes.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, IIS Express may not load your applicationhost.config changes.

trans-unit.source: Enter a new todoitem's text.
trans-unit.target: Enter a new todoitem's text.

trans-unit.source: Then click **Save**.
trans-unit.target: Then click **Save**.

trans-unit.source: This inserts a new todoItem in the database created by the mobile service hosted locally in IIS Express.
trans-unit.target: This inserts a new todoItem in the database created by the mobile service hosted locally in IIS Express.

trans-unit.source: Click the checkbox for one of the items to mark it as completed.
trans-unit.target: Click the checkbox for one of the items to mark it as completed.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio stop debugging the app.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio stop debugging the app.

trans-unit.source: You can view the changes in the database created for the backend service by opening Server Explorer and expanding the Data Connections.
trans-unit.target: You can view the changes in the database created for the backend service by opening Server Explorer and expanding the Data Connections.

trans-unit.source: Right click the TodoItems table under **MS_TableConnectionString** and click **Show Table Data**
trans-unit.target: Right click the TodoItems table under **MS_TableConnectionString** and click **Show Table Data**

trans-unit.source: ![Show data in the table]([14]: ./media/mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-phone-get-started-data/vs-show-local-table-data.png)
trans-unit.target: ![Show data in the table]([14]: ./media/mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-phone-get-started-data/vs-show-local-table-data.png)

trans-unit.source: Once you are finished with your testing with the mobile service hosted locally, delete the Windows Firewall rule you created that opened the port on your workstation.
trans-unit.target: Once you are finished with your testing with the mobile service hosted locally, delete the Windows Firewall rule you created that opened the port on your workstation.

trans-unit.source: Publish the mobile service to Azure
trans-unit.target: Publish the mobile service to Azure

trans-unit.source: Test the mobile service published to Azure
trans-unit.target: Test the mobile service published to Azure

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open App.xaml.cs.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open App.xaml.cs.

trans-unit.source: Comment out the code that creates the `MobileServiceClient` that connects to the locally hosted mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Comment out the code that creates the `MobileServiceClient` that connects to the locally hosted mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Uncomment the code that creates the `MobileServiceClient` that connects to your service in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Uncomment the code that creates the `MobileServiceClient` that connects to your service in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Save your changes to the file.
trans-unit.target: Save your changes to the file.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key or click **Start Debugging** from the Debug menu.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key or click **Start Debugging** from the Debug menu.

trans-unit.source: This will cause the app to be rebuilt with the previous change before running the app to connect to the mobile service hosted remotely in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This will cause the app to be rebuilt with the previous change before running the app to connect to the mobile service hosted remotely in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Enter some new todoitems and click **Save** for each one.
trans-unit.target: Enter some new todoitems and click **Save** for each one.

trans-unit.source: Click the checkbox to complete some of the new items.
trans-unit.target: Click the checkbox to complete some of the new items.

trans-unit.source: Each new todoItem will be stored and updated in the SQL database you previously configured for your mobile service in the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Each new todoItem will be stored and updated in the SQL database you previously configured for your mobile service in the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: You can restart the app to see that the changes were persisted to the database in Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can restart the app to see that the changes were persisted to the database in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You can also examine the database using the Azure Management portal or Visual Studio's SQL Server Object Explorer.
trans-unit.target: You can also examine the database using the Azure Management portal or Visual Studio's SQL Server Object Explorer.

trans-unit.source: The next two steps will use the Azure Management portal to view the changes in your database.
trans-unit.target: The next two steps will use the Azure Management portal to view the changes in your database.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, click manage for the database associated with your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, click manage for the database associated with your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Manage the SQL Database
trans-unit.target: Manage the SQL Database

trans-unit.source: In the Management portal execute a query to view the changes made by the app.
trans-unit.target: In the Management portal execute a query to view the changes made by the app.

trans-unit.source: Your query will be similar to the following query but use your database name instead of `todolist`.
trans-unit.target: Your query will be similar to the following query but use your database name instead of `todolist`.

trans-unit.source: Query the SQL Database
trans-unit.target: Query the SQL Database

trans-unit.source: This concludes the **Get started with data** tutorial.
trans-unit.target: This concludes the **Get started with data** tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: This tutorial demonstrated the basics of enabling a Windows Phone 8 app to work with data in Mobile Services that are built using the .Net runtime.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial demonstrated the basics of enabling a Windows Phone 8 app to work with data in Mobile Services that are built using the .Net runtime.

trans-unit.source: Next, try one of these other tutorials:
trans-unit.target: Next, try one of these other tutorials:

trans-unit.source: Learn how to authenticate users of your app.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to authenticate users of your app.

trans-unit.source: [Add push notifications to your app]()
trans-unit.target: [Add push notifications to your app]()

trans-unit.source: Learn how to send a very basic push notification to your app.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to send a very basic push notification to your app.

trans-unit.source: Learn more about how to use Mobile Services with .NET.
trans-unit.target: Learn more about how to use Mobile Services with .NET.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
